author: @diallo1347
text: My father is a Haitian immigrant and my Mom is American. Growing up, when I was with Mom's family, I was the Haitian boy with the funny name. When I wad with my Dad's family, I was the Amercian bot who couldn't speak Creole and French. The divide is real and self-defeating

replies.author: @N11-xr9pi1
replies.text: Feel ya... My mom is Black American and my dad is Trinidadian [Indo-Trinidadian from a very, very, very mixed Trini family representing so many ethnicities and many complexities with this alone- especially in the US where most folks don't get it].  I grew up primarily with my mom but I am and have always been intimately immersed in both cultures since infancy.  Growing up I was a coconut to my mom's family and a yankee to my dad's family and let me say that this kind of thing kind of persists where ppl take issue with you partaking in, being proud of your cultural heritage on the West Indian side and on the Black American side some folks assume that you don't have a Black American experience b/c you are half Trinidadian. Throw phenotype in the mix and all kind of added BS you dealing with.   Being liminal in this way is added work to the constant work of existing while black in the US.  Tired of the divisiveness in anti Black-American and anti-Caribbean discourses that are out there especially because it gets us nowhere...

replies.author: @murfeel1173
replies.text: SAME EXACT EXPERIENCE, omg!!!

author: @HighAsHeckPriestess
text: When I was growing up in Harlem, where there's a blend of Diaspora folks, I recognized that between nations we all have a massive "greener grass" problem when we try to relate to each other even when it's obvious that no one is really better off than anyone else. American Exceptionalism is a hell of a drug because we can't just be the best but we also gotta be suffering the most, so much so there's Black "educators" with millions of followers out here spreading ahistorical nonsense and fairy tales about experiences that never happened. I wonder if y'all believe that Black people, but Black Americans especially, can find ways to share real truths and build stronger understandings on the internet in an age where rage is more profitable than integrity

author: @zemmym.9437
text:
This is such a Bahamian conversation and I have to share this story that I had sharded on Foriegn's discord a while back.

So I worked part time at a restaurant while going to University. I started talking to this couple who came to eat and struck up a conversation because they just happened to be In the same field that I'm studying right now. They began to talk about look about how they've worked in a bunch of different countries and how India has been foraging a path for technology right now. The guy turns to me and he's like "you know the Indians they aren't the nicest people to work with" and I was like ok fair enough, he continues "they were occupied by Britain the same way The Bahamas was" and in my mind I'm like occupied is a weird way of saying colonized and enslaved but I guess that's how we're wording it. And then this man dead ass looks me in the eye and is like "they didn't exactly learn the same lessons that The Bahamians did"(We are known for being very hospitable)
ü§®
When I say I was flabbergasted, taken aback, bewildered. I didn't know how to respond. What does that even mean???? Like what????

 And the way I just had to smile and nod with that interaction because that's how we've been taught to do that in The Bahamas is wilddd!

replies.author: @mentalhermit

replies.author: @zemmym.9437

replies.author: @mewmew6158
replies.text: Wow, as if Bahamians and Indians weren't both suffering under Britain's colonial rule and aren't still being impacted by that now. The lack of empathy for both groups is awful, made even worse by the way that person admitted that they'd like Indians more as a people if they'd been tortured more. Just gross.

author: @outb4thecount
text: The anti Black American bias in the West Indian community (and African community) is something that has been happening for decades and vice versa. I‚Äôm in my 60‚Äôs and my West Indian grandparents were not thrilled when my dad married an American especially a Southern American who are considered ‚Äúcotton pickers‚Äù with no education or culture. They loved us but I know my mother felt a way about it. She was treated differently and my siblings from my dad‚Äôs first marriage to a West Indian woman were treated differently. On the other hand because my friends knew my dad had West Indian ancestry I was othered many times whether it was being ‚Äúboujie‚Äù or not wearing socks (?). It‚Äôs been a problem.

replies.author: @outb4thecount
replies.text: @carrington2949 Exactly. There was a pipeline from Barbados to South Carolina by the same slave holding families. I have the same surnames on both sides of my family.

replies.author: @thhe5859
replies.text: ‚Å†@outb4thecountYup that‚Äôs very common for people in SC. My family came from the Bahamas pipeline.

replies.author: @Isthatthegrimreaper170
replies.text:
My family is from the Dominican Republic and this sounds like my parents and their families, my mom‚Äôs side of the family are farmers while my dads side were business people and scholars. My mom‚Äôs side of the family ranges from white passing to dark skin while my dad‚Äôs side of the family is allergic to melanin, my mom was very very light skinned but because she came from a poor/mostly brown-skinned family they treated her like the dirt roads they drove on 
I‚Äôm glad they lost all their money and land

replies.text: To completely ignore the message just because of who‚Äôs delivering it is worst. Not everything he says is right, most of what he says is wrong but even a broken clock is right at least twice a day.

replies.author: @TheBest-zi2fp
replies.text: You're getting information from a secondhand source. They mainly focused on one aspect of what Umar said, but besides that there were many inaccuracies in their interpretations of his ideology. He does not view Cassie as white. He's said many times before if you have a black parent (or any amount of black ancestry) and perceive yourself as black, then you are. I don't understand how people forget that Umar's entire platform is Pan-africanism.

replies.author: @sajallday
replies.text: @TheBest-zi2fp Umar is panafrican but his panafricanism excluded LGBT people. That's what's upsetting about him and the people who agree with him.

replies.author: @TheBest-zi2fp
replies.text: @sajallday Umar's a known African traditionalist but I've never seen him "exclude" LGBT people. I don't know what you mean by that. I know he's said he works with the LGBT as a psychologist. Other than that I've only heard him comment on how in White-European culture, homosexuality is normalized as a natural aspect of sexual growth amongst men while in traditional African culture that isn't the case. Correct me if I'm wrong but I don't think he's spoken about LGBT people in a derogatory way at all.

replies.author: @sajallday
replies.text:
@TheBest-zi2fp¬† I'm my experience I've heard a couple things that felt off and I've heard similar from other people. You can work with LGBTQ people and not like them in private, so that could be the case. If I'm mistaken, that is one less blemish on his ideology.

Edit: nvm I just listened to an interview where he implies the government pushed the gay revolution to the forefront was to cover up the murder of black revolutionaries.

replies.author: @TheBest-zi2fp
replies.text: @sajallday What interview was that? That sounds like something he'd say, but even in that statement he seems critical of the government rather than gay people themselves. The worst I've seen from him is a clip of him referring to those who are "sexually confused," which I don't think he elaborated on but I don't know what else he could have meant. Other than that I feel like his homophobia is overblown and people just use it to discredit him.

replies.author: @sajallday
replies.text: @TheBest-zi2fp¬† there was interview on "I Never Knew" youtube channel where he talks about molestation of black boys and black children. And then he connects molestation to ltgbtq. In addition, his gay revolution point is nonsense, because more militant black movements were in the mainstream consciousness during the 60s. The gay revolution was also very black as well and worked in conjuction with black revolutionary movements. So he's intellectually dishonest and homophobic. Which ties back to my point of his brand of "panafricanism" excludes ltgbtq people.

replies.author: @Robstafarian
replies.text: @m3mn0nYT "Eskimo" is the word used by people who do not care to know anything about the Inuit or Yupik people they are discussing.

author: @charlestaylorco8713
text: I loved this conversation and everyone‚Äôs input on American Exceptionalism! I think another perspective to consider, following Tahoe‚Äôs point, is that when speaking on negative/anti-black experiences with Black Immigrants in America, we are looking at a percentage of a percentage. Only a small percentage of the diaspora will make it to the USA, and even a smaller percentage will actually get visas and possibly citizenship. So when Black Americans see those who immigrated and gained wealth, power, etc and may also be attached to Anti-Blackness, we must recognize that it‚Äôs only a minuscule percentage of all Black Immigrants (who are also fed propaganda about Americans) and America is also always attempting to only allow in those they feel will comply to the elite interests.

author: @jnyerere
text:
What Rebecca said towards the end is so relatable. Growing up and going to elementary and middle school in DC, my sisters and I were bullied for being African. By people who looked just like us. But when I went to college at Bowie State (an HBCU) my undergrad experience was the complete opposite of my traumatic childhood. 

Sometimes I look back at college and I don‚Äôt know if I would‚Äôve healed and properly developed my Pan-African politic had I not gone to an HBCU.

author: @laexploradoraaaXD
text: Oh yeah, that blue passport opens doors other people could only dream about seeing. I remember being in line with some UK tourists who realized that since they were no longer part of the EU they had to go stand in line with everyone else. But the US passport holders, we walked right through. Doesn't get more literal than that. People do whatever just so that their children have a chance at getting that blue passport.

author: @hollyrose2418
text: I love the convo about the diaspora wars!

author: @glowy_theythem
text:
I love your videos, you give me opportunities to reflect on generation trauma that has been prevalent in my family. Because when @msolurin said "ppl who made that argument don't care. Because they're looking to move the goal post in order to diminish her." Because that's exactly what was my family's attitude was with my other family members for experiencing domestic abuse & sexual trauma. There's no such thing as a perfect victim. If ppl not going to attack the survivor of DV & ST for staying, then they'll attack them for not fighting back, for not going to get help etc. Forgetting that victims or survivors don't be believed for most of the time. 

Same was said to my family members. Who probably felt like they needed to stay because their abuser destroyed their confidence, their self-worth, they want to stay for their kids or that they lack support, etc. My family, most of the time, lacked that support for my other family members. They sat back & believed "it's her or their fault." "They must've wanted to stay." Yet they never tried to be the actual family they thought they was. Also making excuses for men who do abuse & then making others within the family think that what they do is okay. It's not okay to make excuses for men who hurt others but that's what we've been conditioned to do. Because it's either that or loneliness. That kind of fear doesn't translate well to women in comparison to men. Because men, historical, has always demanded for women's emotional, physical & sexual labor for the loosely threaded promise of safety. That was never going to be fulfilled in a grand scale. No one in my family was for each other. That became a fertile space for more abuse because no one would step in, even if you're a child. I think I said similarly in another comment under your video. I'm not sure. But because of this generational trauma, it denies the humanity & empathy needed for a family to be healthy & loving.

author: @jenisbrowning3447
text: I desperately needed to hear about American exceptionalism, and I have so much work to do. author: @dellydior
text:
I think the issue that we as **African Americans have to get unpack is racial homogenization.A lot of AA‚Äôs here don‚Äôt understand our history and culture here so I think to the power dynamic in a sense,i  think there it adds to the friction as well.like to some,There‚Äôs a sense of ‚ÄúNot belonging ‚Äú Having no culture etc.

  Honestly anybody that‚Äôs black that comes here and becomes a citizen can be a ‚ÄúBlack American‚Äù.Race ethnicity & Nationality are different things and we often conflate the three.tho we use it interchangeably in the community,Context matters.

  The moment we unlearn & deconstruct xenophobia ,the diaspora can really have more unity.we have to educate ourselves about each other ,our experiences coming together while also not erasing one‚Äôs history,Culture etc.definitely starts wit havin real honest conversations and i believe then we‚Äôll be in better alignment ‚ù§Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏èüíØ.Great great show

author: @ceyfzone
text: Just wanna drop M. Jacqui Alexander's Pedagogies of Crossing: Meditations on Feminism, Sexual Politics, Memory, and the Sacred into this. So much of the book resonates with the convo about the Bahamas, (US) tourism, tension within the Black Diaspora, as well as queerness and queer antagonism in in Carribbean culture(s) and legislation.

author: @mrfett
text: It‚Äôs days later and y‚Äôall still got me shook. I played a reggae festival yesterday and the DJ had all the Caribbean people going nuts; it was my first time being in a crowd of immigrants while aware of my privilege being a Puerto Rican. My family came, worked and built wealth. I hadn‚Äôt given thought to how that one fact dramatically alters power dynamics. Education is elevation! Big hugs to you all ü•∞

author: @brutus2115
text:
As a Haitian, I had so many emotions throughout this whole episode lmao but that last speech from Lee hit the nail on the head! End of the day, that‚Äôs what we need to do! A single black political party that is focused on just protecting all black wealth, culture, and heritage. Promoting all black businesses, positivity, and education. And projecting all black power, dollar, and consciousness to form our African Kinship. Take that and we can have our own system that literally intervenes on all levels for black communities and countries worldwide. 

Now this is assuming at least 85% of black america, citizen and immigrant, put their all into this party and an armed self defense force. Not only will we only vote for our own and elect only our own within our spaces so that we maintain control and the narrative regardless of what white America does nationally, but we will also have a security force that will defend our communities and be capable of deploying to wherever they are needed worldwide to physically protect black people. Heck, I‚Äôm a combat Marine Corps veteran. Put me on the team that takes it to the enemy to strike before they can even mobilize. 

Anyways, great episode. Looking forward to your other videos. Moun Podepe, kote nou ye? Men Ayiti nan comments lan! üá≠üáπüá≠üáπüá≠üáπüá≠üáπüá≠üáπüá≠üáπüá≠üáπüá≠üáπüá≠üáπ

author: @tanyabluved
text: I used to be an Umar fan back in college, I stopped messing with him when he went on that rant to Seti. I further stopped checking for him and started exposing how pseudo-intellectual he was and how much of a fraud he is when I found out he was scamming money from the community for a school that still hasn't been built and he started going off on people who really grill him about it i.e. Lord Jamar. You also can't find any credentials proving that he is a PhD. psychologist, but he calls himself Doctor. He likes to talk about the Black family and what caused the destruction of it and what it needs to fix it, yet he has 2-3 children by 2-3 different women. The problem with Umar is that he is such a hypocrite, and even after all his lies and scamming, there are still Black people that fall for the rhetoric. But I'm not shocked as long as it sounds good, Black people love believing anything someone has to say, whether it's in good or bad faith. This is why Umar likes the Breakfast Club because he can spew his BS without being challenged.

Thank you so much for this conversation and discourse. Ngl during the diaspora convo I was itching and nervous and just uncomfortable because I do have personal feelings and hurt from trying to do community with folx outside the black American diaspora and a lot of those friendships did come to an end. But I am sitting with all that‚Äôs been said and learning and reflecting along the way. I pray that we both (black Americans and others throughout the diaspora) are able to decolonize internally and externally so that we can be in real deep community with one another üôèüèΩ
Once again thank you all for this convo üôèüèΩ‚ô•Ô∏è

author: @hardcorechuks
text:
Great conversation, I wanted to expand on the brief mention on Nigeria being an affluent nation. Nigeria has some of the worst wealth distribution in the world and is also quite corrupt, the inequality in wealth can only be understood by people who have lived in similar countries. The difference in everyday life between the rich and poor is outrageous.

In regard to your uncle's comment about not being able to generalise, population is not the only reason why its difficult, Nigeria officially has about 520 languages a third of those languages are unique, the traditions and culture of these different ethnic tribes are very incredibly different from each other. Ideally Nigeria should not be a single nation, but thats a conversation for another day.

text: In regards to Dr.Umar didn't see the BC interview, but i know he generally sides with the fellas and saying Bill Cosby was innocent etc..I think if ppl want to make comparisons we need to do it in a positive way vs. how he allegedly tried to straw man a point. He could've said look we need as much attention as cassie got so we can discuss these type of ills and society, but it's almost as if the arguments say, cassie doesn't deserve that amount attention etc, vs. we should want others to be as valued...it's like when the Milwaukee public school teachers union at one point had great benefits and the other teachers and government employees said we want their benefits cut vs. saying we want benefits just as good.

author: @wandererlyn
text:
The cycles we inherit require intentional deconstruction or we are doomed to repeat...from personal experience of living with my father as an adult with different approaches to life.

For example, we conflict on how to train puppies. My husband and I believe in positive reinforcement and he believes in punishment. 

Sadly for him, our approach leads to better results, and it's been a struggle  to convince a man who hit his own children growing up, not to hit puppies.

author: @SabrinaRina
text:
Ask, how often is colorism used to minimize lighter skinned peoples relatable struggles and NEVER become more attention to darker skinned people's. It then turns into making them the mutual target to hate on for false ideas they have it SO much better.

White people do not treat them white, and black people dont treat them as kin half the time (no pun). They do not get the same level of abuse on race, but they also dont get the same community to get through what they do face.

And 100% its a scapegoat, stawman, and scarier still, that its like a pre-approved victim. Light enough for attention, but dark enough to not be vindicated and only used to perpetuate turmoil within a racial group so we dont focus on the harm, but instead how (usually black people) approach the issue of said harm (SA, DV, general violence, systematic discrimation, etc).
